itemDescription: British medical doctor and Labour Party M.P. (1861-1931)

wikipedia_page.main: Ethel Bentham,  (5 January 1861 – 19 January 1931) was a progressive doctor, a politician and a suffragist in the United Kingdom. She was born in London, educated at Alexandra School and College in Dublin, the London School of Medicine for Women and the Rotunda Hospital.

response: |1800–1874||data-sort-value="Bentham, Ethel"|Ethel Bentham ||United Kingdom||1861||1931||Progressive doctor, politician and suffragette||2003 (reprint). Times Guide to the House of Commons, 1929, 1931, 1935, Politico's, London.
* Ethel Bentham (1861–1931), English doctor, politician and suffragette
* Ethel Bentham (1861–1931) – doctor, politician, member of the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1929 United Kingdom general election

response: The seat had become vacant when the Labour Member of Parliament, Dr Ethel Bentham, died on 19 January 1931, aged 70. She had held the seat since the 1929 general election.
*Ethel Bentham, elected for Islington East in 1929, after standing in 1924, 1923 and 1922.

link_mentions.page: Records of members of parliament of the United Kingdom
response: The oldest woman at first entry to the Commons was Dr Ethel Bentham (born 5 January 1861) who was elected MP for Islington East at the 1929 general election aged 68 years and 145 days. She died in office, the first woman so to do, in 1931.

Tasker was an unsuccessful Conservative candidate at the 1923 general election, when he failed to be elected at Bethnal Green North East. Another election was held in 1924, and Tasker stood again, this time at Islington East. In a three-cornered contest, Tasker defeated the sitting Liberal Member of Parliament (MP), Arthur Comyns Carr. Five years later he was defeated when a swing to Labour saw Ethel Bentham, one of his opponents in 1924, take the seat.

link_mentions.page: Women in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom
response: * 1931: Member to die in office and oldest woman elected (Ethel Bentham) – Labour Party
* Ethel Bentham (1861–1931), Irish doctor, politician and suffragette

*The GP and Labour MP Ethel Bentham died at her home at 100 Beaufort Street in 1931. The travel agent and Women's Royal Naval Service organizer Edith Frances Crowdy subsequently lived there in the 1940s.
Williams was the first female doctor in Newcastle upon Tyne, and in 1906, she became the first woman to found a general medical practice in the city, where she worked alongside Dr Ethel Bentham.
thumb|right|Ethel Bentham, candidate in Islington East

link_mentions.page: Women's International Council of Socialist and Labour Organizations
response: The British Section was formed with Margaret Bondfield as chair, with Margaret McDonald as secretary. Both these women came from the Women's Labour League (WLL). Ethel Bentham, another prominent member of the WLL participated as the representative of the Fabian Society.
